sense.name: trade, deal, or execute a commercial transaction
sense.commentary: NP SELL[+punctual] NP[+count] NP[+count] SELL[+punctual] ADV/PP NP[+agent] SELL[+continuative] NP[+plural/+mass]
sense.examples: He sold the house in January. Harry Potter books have been selling like hotcakes. Movies usually help to sell the video games that are based on them. His uncle sells produce. She didn't want to sell shoes the rest of her life. They are selling oil illegally.

sense.name: persuade or achieve acceptance
sense.commentary: Implies causing a belief or attitude, not a monetary transaction
sense.examples: The idea of gun control doesn't sell well in rural areas. She has sold them on the idea of redecorating their home. She has sold the idea of redecorating to them.

sense.name: relinquish,surrender (usually pejorative)
sense.commentary: NP{+agent] SELL NP Includes: SELL OUT
sense.examples: She sold her principles for a successful career. Judas sold Jesus. You sold her out to the wolves.

sense.name: underestimate the real value or ability of
sense.examples: Don't sell yourself short in college admission essays.

sense.name: get rid of one's goods or possessions
sense.commentary: Includes: SELL OUT, SELL UP, SELL OFF
sense.examples: They sold off their property before they moved. At what price do we sell out out souls? I was fed up with this city, so I sold up all my personal property and moved.

sense.name: selling of securities or commodities at advantageous terms
sense.commentary: SELL SHORT: Method of profiting from a declining stock price by borrowing shares of the stock, selling them at the market price, and then repurchasing the same number of shares at a future date (and at a lower price, if you're lucky) to return them to the original lender.
sense.examples: Investors who sell short believe the price of the stock will fall. So you have sold short 100 shares at $90 each.
